text:
Yeah, I think 
what would be awesome too
is in our vein of legacy

whether you are "I Love Lucy"
or "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles."

You have something 
called these Edge Functions

which are able to, I think,
end up deploying into an environment

and doing some kind of quick logic
to kind of get some kind of calculations out.

So, love to talk a little bit more
about that concept
and how you see that help your customers.
Mm-hmm.

Exactly. So what we've already done, right, 
or we've already covered
is the AWS Greengrass setup,
which, to be fair, is not the most -
you know, the easiest thing to start out with

when you're just trying 
to do some simple calculations, right?

You don't necessarily need
the full-blown Greengrass instance.

You need it obviously,
if you want to do -

if you want to go
into the realm of machine learning

and more complex algorithms
and working with other AWS services,
then Greengrass is great.

But we said, 
there also needs to be a way to -
as fast as connecting devices,  right?

There should also be a way 
to simply add a little JavaScript snippet

and deploy it to a function 
and do some pre-processing of data

or just change the format 
the way you like it

because you want, you know, 
you might not be interested in all data points
or not all properties of the sensor, right?
As we've seen before,

we usually provide them in multiple formats 
for temperature, for instance, right?

But you don't need all of them, right?
I mean, you just need one of them.

So, these little calculations 
or these little snippets,

they make more sense if you can just upload, 
you know, JavaScript code
and deploy that to the boxes

without having to actually spin up 
a Greengrass instance.

So that's kind of where 
we're coming from for this part and...

it's pretty quick to also do things 
like, you know, averaging
or using min-max values over time

or just going for a kind of low-data approach
where you can set boundaries in code
and say that, you know:

"I'm only interested in that temperature value
when it goes above X degree, right?

I don't need it below that;
I just need it when it goes above that."

So these kinds of thing and situations
we can cover pretty easily.
